Differences aside, I applaud Pete for his comprehensive plan. National service will help unify the country, heal the wounds of partisanship and hate, build strong communities, and tackle big challenges like climate change. 

Every candidate should support these goals.

Finally, my plan rewards those who serve with tuition and job-training funding modeled on the GI Bill. 

The same concept that built our middle class after WWII is exactly how we should strengthen the middle class today.

My plan elevates the head of the program to a cabinet level, but the Chief Service Officer shouldn't be on the National Security Council. Having the National Service head work on security issues would detract from the plan's purpose: making American communities stronger.

Pete should go bigger.

We want at least one million volunteers to serve in the first year‚Äîthe economic multiplier would result in a great return on investment. The plan should be at least able to accommodate all who applied to AmeriCorps & Peace Corps last year.

There are important differences between our plans. I am asking all young people to consider serving‚Äîunifying the country through national service means we want people from all walks of life to work shoulder-to-shoulder to solve our biggest challenges.

I commend Mayor Pete for joining me in the effort to dramatically increase national service in our country.

I strongly encourage all of the other candidates to develop their own national service plans or sign on to mine:  https://sethmoulton.com/national-service/¬†‚Ä¶
